abstracts.cdata!:
Overall, the project is rated
            unsatisfactory, sustainability is unlikely, and the
            institutional development impact is modest. Given that the
            objective of the project was to improve public sector
            accounting, there is a lesson to be learned in terms of the
            Bank's allocation of human resources to design,
            implement, supervise, and evaluate such a macro financial
            management-oriented project. There should be an appropriate
            mix of public sector accounting, and information technology
            (IT) skills, to ensure appropriate project design, in
            accordance with the country's environment. Other
            valuable lessons address the need for frequent supervision,
            particularly when multi-year systems development is
            involved, to obtain objective assessments of project status;
            similarly, complex IT projects should be avoided; instead,
            for accounting systems, off-the-shelf accounting packages
            are a preferable alternative, i.e., if modifications to
            software, and business processes are required, these may be
            tailored to user requirements, and, for significant software
            changes, pilot testing could be a strategy, in the absence
            of implementation capacity. Most importantly, the
            country's human resource capacity should be carefully
            evaluated prior to the Bank advising on modernization, and
            reforms: the project was far beyond the technical, and human
            resource capacity of the Government to operate high-tech systems.
